text: Solvency II Article 101 requires that capital be sufficient to cover 99.5% of annual risk.
NAIC Risk-Based Capital (RBC) guidelines require tail-risk stress testing for catastrophe treaties.
IFRS 17 mandates transparent reporting of expected losses and reinsurance recoverables.
Treaty coverage must align with the insurer’s capital buffer and retention strategy.
Excess-of-loss treaties require reinsurer participation to be well diversified.
Catastrophe treaty exposures must pass 1-in-200 year Probable Maximum Loss (PML) stress tests.
Under Solvency II, ceded premium levels must not reduce the insurer’s Minimum Capital Requirement below thresholds.
Reinsurance contracts should provide risk transfer under US SSAP No. 62 guidelines.
Retrocession agreements must not concentrate exposure in a single reinsurer beyond 25% of total ceded risk.
IFRS 17 requires discounting of future cash flows in reinsurance contract measurement.
Reinsurance contracts must contain clear terms for loss notification and settlement to satisfy audit requirements.
Quota share treaties must limit cessions to preserve primary insurer risk appetite and alignment.
All catastrophe treaties must comply with local solvency stress testing for hurricane and earthquake scenarios.
Under Solvency II, reinsurance recoverables must be adjusted for counterparty credit quality.
NAIC requires reinsurers to be licensed or provide collateral for US credit for reinsurance treatment.
Excess-of-loss treaties should consider reinstatement provisions to ensure multi-event protection.
Reinsurance contracts must define occurrence limits for aggregation under IFRS 17 reporting.
Facultative placements must include due diligence on insured risk profiles to avoid anti-selection.
Climate change risk assessments should be incorporated into property catastrophe reinsurance treaties.
Reinsurance programs must be reviewed annually to confirm alignment with Board-approved risk appetite.
